narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' will generate several types of scientific data. These include demographic and clinical data (tabular) collected from 110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls, as well as MRI-based imaging data. The MRI data will encompass structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS, along with derived imaging measures/features. Supporting documentation such as data dictionaries, protocols, and README files will also be generated. The total volume of the dataset is expected to be substantial, with participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants and multi-modal MRI imaging data.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project, including demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data, will be deidentified and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to maximize their utility for future research, facilitating advancements in understanding and treating conditions affecting youth. Sharing deidentified data ensures that the privacy of human research participants is protected while allowing the broader scientific community to benefit from the data.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata and documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments, data dictionaries explaining variable definitions, README files detailing data processing steps, and any other information necessary for understanding the context and content of the shared data. These resources will enable users to comprehend the structure, quality, and potential limitations of the data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code may be needed to access or manipulate certain aspects of the shared scientific data, particularly for analyzing MRI imaging data. For example, software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages) might be required for processing and analyzing fMRI and structural MRI data. Additionally, tools like 3D Slicer could be necessary for visualizing and segmenting anatomical structures from MRI scans. These tools are widely available in the research community, with some being open-source and others requiring registration or institutional access.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. For MRI imaging data, the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) recommendations will be followed to standardize data organization and description. This facilitates easier sharing, aggregation, and analysis of neuroimaging data across studies. Additionally, for tabular demographic and clinical data, standards such as those proposed by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) for clinical research data will be adopted, ensuring consistency in variable naming, formatting, and documentation.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), which is an NIH-designated data repository for human subjects research. The NDA provides a secure, centralized platform for storing, sharing, and accessing human subjects data, ensuring that data are properly deidentified and made available to qualified researchers.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers (PUIs) assigned by the NDA. Each dataset will be associated with a DOI (Digital Object Identifier), facilitating its citation in publications and enabling easy tracking and access to the data.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings from the project or at the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Data will remain available for a minimum of 10 years following the end of the project to allow for extended research use and validation of findings.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While this project aims to maximize data sharing, factors such as informed consent limitations and privacy protections may affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse. Given that all research participants will provide broad consent for data sharing, these limitations are expected to be minimal. However, any personally identifiable information (PII) or protected health information (PHI) will be removed from shared datasets to protect participant confidentiality.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be controlled in the sense of requiring approval for each use. Once archived in the NDA and associated publications are released, the data will be available to any qualified researcher who agrees to the terms of use set forth by the NDA, including requirements for protecting participant privacy.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be deidentified. This involves removing direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and indirect identifiers that could potentially reveal individual identities when combined with other publicly available information. Additionally, the project will comply with relevant regulations such as HIPAA for health information and will obtain a Certificate of Confidentiality from the NIH to further safeguard participant data.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. The PI, along with designated data managers and the institutional review board (IRB), will ensure that all aspects of data collection, storage, sharing, and protection are conducted according to the plan and relevant policies and regulations. Oversight activities will include regular reviews of data sharing progress, ensuring that datasets are properly deidentified before sharing, and maintaining documentation of data requests and uses. This oversight will be conducted at least bi-annually during the project's active phase and annually thereafter for as long as the data remain available.
